_header: There nis so high comfort to my pleasance
Author(s): Geoffrey Chaucer; Oton de Graunson Sir
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, ‘Complaint of Venus’, from the French of Sir Oton de Graunson — nine eight-line stanzas (possibly three balades) and 10-line Envoy

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
There nys non sa hie confort to my plesanceQuhen þat I am In
                    any heuyness…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…To folowe word all the curiositeeOff Graunsoun the best
                    þat matrith france
BodArcSelB24.Facsimiles:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards, eds.  
             Chaucer, Works. Bodleian Library MS Arch Selden B.24: Facsimile
                Edition.
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1995.
BodArcSelB24.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BodAsh59.First Lines:
And to resceyve þis compleynte in greeVn to youre excellent
                    benignyteeDirecte affter my litel suffisaunceffor eelde in my spirit
                    so dulleþe me…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…ffor to folowe by wordes þe curyousteeOf hem þat
                    vsen for to make in ffraunce
BodAsh59.Note:
10 lines; occurs at the end of Chaucer’s ‘Fortune’
                        (5803-4); second
                    occurrence in this manuscript.

BodFair16.First Lines:
Ther nys so high comfort to my plesaunceWhen that I am in eny
                    heuynesse…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…To folowe worde by worde the curiositeof graunson floure of
                    hem that maken in fraunce
BodFair16.Note:
Preceded by 1518 and
                    treated as if one work; includes 10-line envoy beginning, ‘Princes
                    resseyueth this compleynt in gre’ (ff. 20-20v).
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.
BodFair16.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967. 
Robinson,  F. N.,
                        ed.  
             The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1933; 2nd ed. 1957: 633-4; 1957, 537-8.
Benson,  Larry Dean,
                        ed.  
             The Riverside Chaucer.
         3rd ed. Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1987: 648-9.

BodTan346.First Lines:
Ther nys none so hieh comforte to my plesaunceWhen that I am in eny
                    heuynesse…
BodTan346.Last Lines:
…To folow worde by worde the curiositeOf gransoun flor of hem
                    that make in fraunse

CULFf16.First Lines:
There nys so high comfort to my plesaunceWhanne that y am in any
                    hevynesseAs for to haue leyser of remembraunceVpon the manhoode and
                    the worthynesse…
CULFf16.Last Lines:
…To folwen word be word the curiositeOf Graunson flour of hem
                    þat maken in ffraunce
CULFf16.Facsimiles:
Beadle,  Richard,  and  Alfred E. B. Owen.  
             The Findern Manuscript: Cambridge University Library MS. F.1.6.
         London: Scolar Press, 1977.

Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
…Thus be euer in drede and suffryngeIn none certene wee
                    langwishe in penaunce…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…To folowen word by word the curiositeOf Grawnsoun floure of
                    hem þat make in ffraunce
CamMagPep2006.Note: Begins imperfectly top p. 381 at line 45.
CamMagPep2006.Facsimiles:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Pepys 2006: A Facsimile. Magdalen College,
                Cambridge.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and [Woodbridge, Suffolk]: Boydell and Brewer,
            1985.

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Þer nys so hye counfort to my plesaunceWhane þat I am in
                    any hevynesseAs for to haue leyser of RemembraunceVpon þe
                    manhoode and þe Worþynesse…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…To folowen word y word þe curyosyteeOf Graunsomme flour
                    of hem þat make in ffraunce
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
þus eondeþe here þis complaint whiche some men sayne was
                    made by my…and filowing begynneþe a balade translated out of frenshe
                    in to englisshe by Chaicier Geffrey þe frenshe made sir Otes de Grauntsoune
                    knight Savosyen (p. 139); A Balade made by Chaucer At þe reverence of a
                    lady þat loved a knyght (RT); Hit is sayde þat Graunsomme made
                    þis last balade for venus resembled to my lady of york aunswering þe
                    complaynt of Mars (p. 142)
CamTCC600.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967. 
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Supplementary Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor
                Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 22, 59. London: Trübner, n.d.; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
Princis receyvith this complaynt in greeVnto yowre excelent
                    benyngnite…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…ffor to folowe by wordis the curiositeOf them that vsen for
                    ta make in fraunce
BLHar2251.Note:
‘Envoy’ only, following as if part of the same poem,
                    ‘Truth’ (5803).
